message: "Data management with real and simulated semi-conductors"

I'm just looking at strengths of the group here: 1) Jes -  a chemist at UCSB; 2) Jason - Semiconductor circuit characterization based on SPICE; 3) Anthony - physicist and "Mr Python" 4) Me (Sean) - Computer Engineering major;
@SeanKnudsen Well we all have some knowledge of semi-conductors is what ties this show together.
@SeanKnudsen Also I'd like it to have more of a 'real' world feel.  Jason and I can handle the software side of cirs.

Thought I had today: On the software side, many programmers loose sight of the fact that what we code actually manipulates real physical processes.  Moreover, someone(s) had to design these processes.  I would like to talk about the implications for so many people to be so abstracted away from the physics / chemistry.

It is like we as humans have built this tool that not even the tool builders know how to build.  Has this ever happened before in human history?

@Scoptz Not only programmers, but chip designers, too.  I am surprised by how many digital logic designers forget that the underlying circuits are really analog.  I had one engineer ask why our "measured" (meaning SPICE) capacitance numbers for an input pin were different than his reference library. I explained that SPICE settings and measurement methodology all change the value. And he said, "but SPICE is SPICE, which one is right? It's just a capacitor, right?" Oh no...
For recording on Tuesday, I am possibly available before 5pm but have a charity dinner thing to go to at 5pm. Any chance we could record earlier?
I'm in California...It'd be nice if I could record after work. Earliest i could do would be 5PM PST.
@SeanKnudsen Which is 7pm my time.  This makes it seem like Wednesday may be better....

I can't contribute much to discussing software aside from a few gripes here and there.  I'll probably just stick to talking about toys.  Characterization instruments?  Testing equipment?  Alternatively, how to build transistors/diodes from organic materials?  How to deal with the deluge of data that results from testing such devices?

@CBC_psi "How to deal with the deluge of data that results from testing such devices?" is what I would like to focus on... Or at least hit.  I imagine that there will also be lots of talking about toys ;).

I'm not sure what to say about too much testing data...i have a pretty straightforward feedback process at my work - test, fix, test fix. I generate lots of excel data sometimes, but there's always a way to cut down and get what you need graphed
@SeanKnudsen Do you put your excel data under version control?
